Abstract: This study explores the contributions of a pioneering woman scientist in the field of psychophysics, focusing on her groundbreaking work in color vision, hyperacuity, and stereopsis. Through an autobiographical lens, the research delves into her innovative approaches to understanding trajectory motion and amblyopia, highlighting her influence on contemporary vision science. By examining her scientific journey, the paper sheds light on the challenges and triumphs faced by women in science, offering insights into her enduring legacy. This narrative not only celebrates her achievements but also inspires future generations of women scientists to pursue their passions in psychophysics.
